children.name: when the real situation is different from what people think
actually
children.definition: /ˈæktʃuəli, -tʃəli/  especially spoken used to tell or ask someone what the real situation is, when they think it is something different:

children.name: ▪ ‘Here’s the $10 I owe you.’ ‘Actually, you owe me 20.’
examples: ▪ Did he actually hit you or just threaten you?
▪ It turns out that one of the children I thought was a girl was actually a boy.

children.name: in fact
children.definition: used to tell someone what the real situation is, when they think it is something different.Actuallyis more informal and is used more in conversation than in fact. Actually is also used more in questions than in fact.Actuallyis often used at the beginning of a sentence that answers a question, but in fact is not.:
examples: ▪ He said it would be cheap but in fact it cost over £200.
▪ No, I’m not offended at all. In fact, I’m glad you asked the question.

children.name: in actual fact/in point of fact
examples: ▪They seem to think that building a new road will improve the traffic problem, whereas in point of fact it will make it worse.
▪ There are almost 200,000 possible combinations of symbols. In actual fact, only a small number of these are used.

children.name: really
children.definition: /ˈrɪəli/  spoken used to say what the truth is, especially because something about the situation may make people believe something that is wrong: đúng là, thật ra là
examples: He failed his tests, but he’s quite a bright guy, really.

children.name: Are you sure she’s really a lawyer? She doesn’t act like one
examples: They’re asking £600,000 for the house. That’s more than it’s really worth.

children.name: in reality
children.definition: /the reality is/ɪn riˈælti, ðə riˈælti ɪz/  used to introduce the second part of a statement when you want to show that the first part is not true or exact:Sự thật, trong thực tế, thực tế là
examples: ▪ It seems like just yesterday, but in reality it was five years ago.
Nó trong như chỉ mới hôm qua, nhưng sự thật thì nó đã là 5 năm trước.
▪ Nowadays owning a car may appear to be a necessity, but in reality it isn’t.
Ngày nay sở hữu một chiếc xe có vẻ như là một điều cần thiết, nhưng sự thật không phải vậy.
▪ They say that the economy is already coming out of the recession, but the reality is that there has been no improvement at all.
Họ nói nền kinh tế đã thoát khỏi suy thoái rồi, nhưng trong thực tế thì đã chẳng có sự cải thiện nào cả.
the reality of the situation is
sự thật của vấn đề là
▪ The reality of the situation is that by sending drug users to jail, the government may be discouraging people from seeking treatment.
Sự thật của vấn đề là bằng cách cho những con nghiện thuốc vào ngục, chính phủ có vẻ đang can ngăn mọi người tìm sự điều trị.

children.name: the fact is
children.definition: the fact/ truth isB1 used to show what the real truth or fact is in a situation, when this is surprising or different from what people believed was true: sự thật là
examples: ▪ The truth was that she did not enjoy getting together with the rest of her family.
▪ The fact is he was murdered. He didn’t commit suicide at all.
▪ I may make it all look easy, but the truth is I work very hard.

children.name: in practice
children.definition: /ɪn ˈprækts/  used to show the difference between what is supposed to happen according to a rule or law, and what does happen:trên thực tế (trái, ngược với luật lệ)
examples: ▪ Teenagers are not allowed to drink in bars, but in practice they often do.
Thiếu niên không được phép uống rượu trong các hộp đêm, nhưng trên thực tế thì chúng thường làm việc đó.
▪ Economic predictions are highly theoretical. It’s what they mean in practice that is important.
Những tiên đoán về kinh tế phần lớn chỉ là lý thuyết suông. Chúng như thế nào trong thực tế mới là quan trọng.

children.name: in theory ... in practice
examples: ▪ The law seemed like a good idea in theory, but in practice it has proved far too expensive.
Luật có vẻ là một ý tưởng hay trên lý thuyết, nhưng trong thực tế nó đã được chứng minh là quá xa hoa.

children.name: in effect
children.definition: /effectivelyC2 used to show what really happens, even though this was not clear from what was said or done: thực tế
examples: ▪ Foreign companies have been effectively running the country for decades.
▪ Management seems to be saying, in effect, that if we don’t like the offer, we can all quit.

children.name: when what really happens is different from stories, films etc
in the real world
children.definition: /ɪn ðə ˈrɪəl ˌwɜːʳld/  in the world in which people really live, not in the world which exists in people’s imagination:

children.name: trong thế giới thực
examples: ▪ Romances of that kind don’t happen in the real world.
Những sự lãng mạn như vậy không xảy ra trong thế giới thực.
▪ In the real world no one actually dies of a broken heart, but it happens in operas all the time.
Trong thế giới thực không ai thật sự chết bởi một trái tim tan vỡ, nhưng nó luôn luôn diễn ra trong những vở opera.
▪ His sudden success is something you never really expect to happen in the real world.
Sự thành công bất ngờ của anh ấy là thứ mà bạn không bao giờ có thể mong đợi xảy ra trong thế giới thực.

children.name: in real life
children.definition: /ɪn ˌrɪəl ˈlaɪf/  in real life, as opposed to what happens in films or stories:

children.name: Ở ngoài đời
examples: ▪ In real life there’s no magic wand to make all our problems disappear.
Ngoài đời không hề có gậy phép để làm biến mất tất cả những vấn đề của chúng ta.
▪ On TV he plays a teenager, but in real life he’s married with two children.
Trên TV anh ấy diễn vai một thiếu niên, nhưng ở ngoài đời anh ấy đã kết hôn và có 2 đứa con.

children.name: actually
children.definition: There are many stories which describe wolves as dangerous, blood-thirsty animals, but  they prefer to avoid human beings.

children.name: when you want to add sth surprising or interesting to what you are saying
actually
examples: Robert’s an old friend of mine. We were at school together, actually.
I didn't like him at first, but in the end I actually got quite fond of him.
I'm one of the few people who doesn't actually like champagne.
humorous Don't tell me he actually paid for you!

children.name: as a matter of fact
examples: ▪ The company is doing very well. As a matter of fact, we’ve doubled our sales budget.

children.name: in fact
examples: ▪ Of course I know your mother. We go to the same church, in fact.
▪ The performance was excellent. In fact, it was probably the best I’ve seen.
